content.title: Cerebral Hyperperfusion Syndrome After Carotid Intervention

statement.text: Cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) is a rare but devastating complication of carotid revascularization characterized by unilateral headache, seizures, and potentially intracerebral hemorrhage due to sudden increase in cerebral blood flow to a chronically hypoperfused hemisphere.
statement.formal: Incidence: 1-3% post-CEA/CAS; Triad: Ipsilateral headache, seizures, focal deficits; Risk: Severe stenosis, poor collaterals, hypertension; Prevention: Strict BP control

explanation.intuition: After years of living with reduced blood flow, the brain's blood vessels lose their ability to constrict. When we suddenly restore full blood flow, these 'lazy' vessels can't tighten up, and too much blood floods into the brain tissue, causing swelling or bleeding.
explanation.key_insight: Strict blood pressure control post-CEA is the cornerstone of CHS prevention - even 'normal' pressures can be dangerously high for a hypoperfused brain.
explanation.technical_details: Cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome results from impaired cerebral autoregulation in chronically hypoperfused brain. After revascularization, cerebral blood flow can increase 2-3 fold. With defective autoregulation, small arterioles cannot constrict, leading to capillary leak, cerebral edema, and potentially hemorrhagic stroke. Risk factors include severe stenosis (>90%), contralateral occlusion, recent stroke, and perioperative hypertension. The classic triad is ipsilateral headache, seizures, and focal neurologic deficits. Treatment focuses on aggressive blood pressure control.
common_misconceptions: CHS only occurs in the first 24 hours - FALSE, can occur up to 2 weeks post-op
Normal blood pressure is safe post-CEA - FALSE, may need lower than usual BP targets
CHS is just a headache - FALSE, can progress to fatal intracerebral hemorrhage
Only CEA causes CHS - FALSE, also occurs after carotid stenting

chronic_hypoperfusion.result: Inability to constrict when flow increases

procedural: Both CEA and CAS carry similar risk

diagnosis.clinical: High index of suspicion with headache post-CEA/CAS

intracerebral_hemorrhage.neurosurgery: Consult for hematoma evacuation if indicated

definition.@value: A complication of carotid revascularization characterized by excessive cerebral blood flow due to impaired autoregulation, manifesting as headache, seizures, and potentially intracerebral hemorrhage.

diagnosis: CT head to rule out hemorrhage

sources.reference: Systematic reviews on CHS incidence and risk factors

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome
Recognize clinical presentation and implement appropriate workup
clinical_pearls: Post-CEA headache is a red flag - may herald hyperperfusion
Strict BP control (SBP <140) for at least 1-2 weeks post-op
CHS can occur up to 2 weeks after procedure
Intracerebral hemorrhage from CHS has 40-50% mortality
High-risk: >90% stenosis, contralateral occlusion, recent stroke
